description: Borrowed from Malay adat, from Persian عادة‎, from Arabic عَادَة‎ (ʕāda, “habit, custom”), from the verb عَوْدَ‎ (ʕawda, “to appertain, to be proper”).

entries.meaning: Traditional custom or law, in Islamic parts of Southeast Asia. [from 18th c.]
examples: [T]he early-nineteenth-century Padri movement  […]  was an accelerated programme of religious renewal in West Sumatra, an attempt to cleanse Islam of adat or local customary law and practices.
